#Text=Justice KAGAN delivered the opinion of the Court .
#Text=To help staunch a " flood of nonmeritorious " prisoner litigation , the Prison Litigation Reform Act of 1995 ( PLRA ) established what has become known as the three - strikes rule .

column1: #Text=That rule generally prevents a prisoner from bringing suit in forma pauperis ( IFP) - that is , without first paying the filing fee - if he has had three or more prior suits " dismissed on the grounds that [ they were ] frivolous , malicious , or fail[ed ] to state a claim upon which relief may be granted . "

column1: #Text=Today we address whether a suit dismissed for failure to state a claim counts as a strike when the dismissal was without prejudice .
#Text=We conclude that it does : The text of Section 1915(g ) 's three - strikes provision refers to any dismissal for failure to state a claim , whether with prejudice or without .
#Text=I
#Text=Petitioner Arthur Lomax is an inmate in a Colorado prison .
#Text=He filed this suit against respondent prison officials to challenge his expulsion from the facility 's sex - offender treatment program .
#Text=As is common in prison litigation , he also moved for IFP status to allow his suit to go forward before he pays the $ 400 filing fee .
#Text=For that motion to succeed , Lomax must avoid Section 1915(g ) .
#Text=That provision bars further IFP litigation once a prisoner has had at least three prior suits dismissed on specified grounds .
#Text=And Lomax is no rookie litigant .
#Text=During his time in prison , he has already brought three unsuccessful legal actions ( against various corrections officers , prosecutors , and judges ) .
#Text=If the dispositions of those cases qualify as strikes under Section 1915(g ) , Lomax may not now proceed IFP .
#Text=The courts below ruled that Lomax had struck out .

#Text=The District Court denied his motion for IFP status , finding that all three of his prior suits had been dismissed for failure to state a claim - one of the grounds specified in Section 1915(g ) .
#Text=See App . 65 - 66 .
#Text=On appeal , Lomax argued that two of those dismissals should not count as strikes because they were without prejudice , thus allowing him to file a later suit on the same claim .
#Text=The Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit rejected that argument .
#Text=Relying on Circuit precedent , the Court held it " immaterial to the strikes analysis " whether a dismissal was with or without prejudice .

column1: #Text=754 Fed . Appx . 756 , 759 ( 2018 ) ( quoting Childs v. Miller , 713 F.3d 1262 , 1266 ( CA10 2013 ) ) .
#Text=The Courts of Appeals have long divided over whether a dismissal without prejudice for failure to state a claim qualifies as a strike under Section 1915(g ) .
#Text=In line with our duty to call balls and strikes , we granted certiorari to resolve the split , 589 U. S. ---- , 140 S.Ct . 428 , 205 L.Ed.2d 244 ( 2019 ) , and we now affirm .
#Text=II
#Text=This case begins , and pretty much ends , with the text of Section 1915(g ) .
#Text=Under that provision , a prisoner accrues a strike for any action " dismissed on the ground [ ] that it ... fails to state a claim upon which relief may be granted . "
#Text=That broad language covers all such dismissals : It applies to those issued both with and without prejudice to a plaintiff 's ability to reassert his claim in a later action .
#Text=A strike - call under Section 1915(g )
#Text=thus hinges exclusively on the basis for the dismissal , regardless of the decision 's prejudicial effect .
#Text=To reach the opposite result - counting prejudicial orders alone as strikes - we would have to read the simple word " dismissed " in Section 1915(g ) as " dismissed with prejudice . "

column3:
*[22]	Direct Quote[22]

32-24	3579-3580

column1: #Text=But this Court may not narrow a provision 's reach by inserting words Congress chose to omit .
#Text=See , e.g. , Virginia Uranium , Inc. v. Warren , 587 U. S. ---- , ---- , 139 S.Ct . 1894 , 1900 , 204 L.Ed.2d 377 ( 2019 ) ( lead opinion of GORSUCH , J. ) .

#Text=Indeed , to do so would violate yet another rule of statutory construction : " In all but the most unusual situations , a single use of a statutory phrase must have a fixed meaning " across a statute .

column1: #Text=Cochise Consultancy , Inc. v. United States ex rel . Hunt , 587 U. S. ---- , ---- , 139 S.Ct . 1507 , 1512 , 203 L.Ed.2d 791 ( 2019 ) .
#Text=The PLRA includes three other provisions mentioning " dismiss[als ] " for " fail[ure ] to state a claim"-each enabling courts to dismiss sua sponte certain prisoner suits on that ground .
#Text=No one here thinks those provisions deprive courts of the ability to dismiss those suits without prejudice .
#Text=See Reply Brief 15 ; Brief for Respondents 21 - 24 ; Brief for United States as Amicus Curiae 21 - 22 .
#Text=Nor would that be a plausible position .

#Text=The broad statutory language - on its face covering dismissals both with and without prejudice - tracks courts ' ordinary authority to decide whether a dismissal for failure to state a claim should have preclusive effect .
#Text=So reading the PLRA 's three - strikes rule to apply only to dismissals with prejudice would introduce inconsistencies into the statute .
#Text=The identical phrase would then bear different meanings in provisions almost next - door to each other .
#Text=Still , Lomax maintains that the phrase " dismissed [ for ] fail[ure ] to state a claim " in Section 1915(g ) is a " legal term of art " referring only to dismissals with prejudice .

column1: #Text=Reply Brief 4 .
#Text=To support that view , he relies on a procedural rule used to answer a different question .
#Text=When a court dismisses a case for failure to state a claim , but neglects to specify whether the order is with or without prejudice , how should a later court determine its preclusive effect ?

#Text=Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(b ) , codifying an old equitable principle , supplies the answer : It tells courts to treat the dismissal " as an adjudication on the merits"-meaning a dismissal with prejudice .

column1: #Text=Brief for Petitioner 17 .

#Text=He reasons : Because Rule 41(b ) presumes that an order stating only " dismissed for failure to state a claim " is with prejudice , the same language when used in Section 1915(g ) should bear that same meaning .

column1: #Text=And if so , the provision would assign a strike to only with - prejudice dismissals for failure to state a claim .
#Text=But that argument gets things backwards .

#Text=The Rule 41(b ) presumption ( like its older equitable counterpart ) does not convert the phrase " dismissed for failure to state a claim " into a legal term of art meaning " dismissed with prejudice " on that ground .

column1: #Text=To the contrary , Rule 41(b ) is necessary because that phrase means only what it says : " dismissed for failure to state a claim"-whether or not with prejudice .

column1: #Text=In other words , the phrase 's indifference to prejudicial effect is what creates the need for a default rule to determine the import of a dismissal when a court fails to make that clear .
#Text=Rule 41(b ) , then , actually undercuts Lomax 's position : Its very existence is a form of proof that the language used in Section 1915(g ) covers dismissals both with and without prejudice .
#Text=And here too , confirmation of the point comes from the PLRA 's other provisions referring to " dismiss[als ] " for " fail[ure ] to state a claim . "
#Text=See supra , at 1725 .

#Text=If that phrase had really become a legal term of art implying " with prejudice , " then those provisions would prevent courts from dismissing prisoner suits without prejudice for failure to state a claim .
#Text=But Lomax himself does not accept that improbable reading .
#Text=See ibid .
#Text=His supposed " term of art " is strangely free - floating , transforming ordinary meaning in one place while leaving it alone in all others .

column1: #Text=Lomax also makes an argument based on the two other grounds for dismissal listed in Section 1915(g ) .
#Text=Recall that the provision counts as strikes dismissals of actions that are " frivolous " or " malicious , " along with those that fail to state a claim .
#Text=See supra , at 1723 , 1724 , n. 1 .
#Text=In Lomax 's view , the first two kinds of dismissals " reflect a judicial determination that a claim is irremediably defective"-that it " can not succeed and should not return to court . "

#Text=Id. , at 23 ; see i d. , at 21 ( invoking the " interpretive canon noscitur a sociis , a word is known by the company it keeps " ( internal quotation marks omitted ) ) .

column1: #Text=So Section 1915(g ) , Lomax concludes , must capture only the subset of those dismissals that are issued with prejudice - the ones disposing of " irredeemable " suits .
#Text=Id. , at 21 .
#Text=As an initial matter , the very premise of that argument is mistaken .
#Text=Contra Lomax 's view , courts can and sometimes do conclude that frivolous actions are not " irremediably defective , " and thus dismiss them without prejudice .

column1: #Text=See , e.g. , Marts v. Hines , 117 F.3d 1504 , 1505 ( CA5 1997 ) ; see also Jackson v. Florida Dept . of Financial Servs . , 479 Fed . Appx . 289 , 292 ( CA11 2012 ) ( similarly if less commonly , dismissing a malicious action without prejudice ) .

#Text=Indeed , this Court has suggested that a trial court might abuse its discretion by dismissing an IFP suit with prejudice if " frivolous factual allegations [ can ] be remedied through more specific pleading . "

column1: #Text=Denton v. Hernandez , 504 U.S. 25 , 34 , 112 S.Ct . 1728 , 118 L.Ed.2d 340 ( 1992 ) .
#Text=So on Lomax 's own metric - whether down the road the plaintiff 's claim might return - the dismissals he claims would be outliers in Section 1915(g ) in fact would have company .
#Text=And because that is true , his reason for excluding those decisions from the provision collapses .
#Text=If dismissals without prejudice for frivolousness count as a strike under Section 1915(g ) , then why not for failure to state a claim too ?
#Text=Still more fundamentally , Lomax is wrong to suggest that every dismissed action encompassed in Section 1915(g ) must closely resemble frivolous or malicious ones .
#Text=The point of the PLRA , as its terms show , was to cabin not only abusive but also simply meritless prisoner suits .
#Text=Before the PLRA , the statute governing IFP claims targeted frivolous and malicious actions , but no others .
#Text=See Neitzke v. Williams , 490 U.S. 319 , 328 , 109 S.Ct . 1827 , 104 L.Ed.2d 338 ( 1989 ) .
#Text=In the PLRA , Congress chose to go further - precisely by aiming as well at actions that failed to state a claim .
#Text=The theory was that a " flood of nonmeritorious claims , " even if not in any way abusive , was " effectively preclud[ing ] consideration of " suits more likely to succeed .
#Text=Jones , 549 U.S. at 203 , 127 S.Ct . 910 .
#Text=So we can not , in the interest of " harmonization , " interpret the phrase " failure to state a claim " based on the pre - existing terms " frivolous " and " malicious . "

#Text=Cf . Babbitt v. Sweet Home Chapter , Communities for Great Ore. , 515 U.S. 687 , 702 , 705 , 115 S.Ct . 2407 , 132 L.Ed.2d 597 ( 1995 ) ( rejecting use of the noscitur canon when " the Senate went out of its way to add " a " broad word " to a statute ) .

column1: #Text=That would defeat the PLRA 's expansion of the statute beyond what was already there .
#Text=III
#Text=The text of the PLRA 's three - strikes provision makes this case an easy call .
#Text=A dismissal of a suit for failure to state a claim counts as a strike , whether or not with prejudice .
#Text=We therefore affirm the judgment below .
#Text=It is so ordered .
